book.title: De iuris arte, methodo, et praeceptis

marginalia.translation:
Grammar. 1. External or speech. { General or common. { Rhetoric. 2. Form II. { Internal or reason. { Logic. 3.
Special or particular.{ Nomological or legal. { The law itself, its soul, reason. 4. { that which is to be deliberated. that which is to be settled. 1.2. Lorenzo Valla praises a [?mirifire?] style in the preface of the third book of the 'Elegancies'. 3. Pierre Gregoire, Doctor of Canon and Civil Law, examines and discusses the method in chapter two of 'De iuris arte, methodo, et praeceptis', where it is, in general, in this way. Certainly, we can defend in some way the order in the body of laws [pandectes]. But, actually, it is not like this, because the 'Arte' is digested. Many things can, and should, be more appropriately positioned than where they are placed, but they are arranged according to the order as it is taught by [?consareinatores?] of law. Add here the judgement of Dr Thomas Smith in the 'Legal Preface'.
Also Francois Douaren, book one of 'Disputationum anniversariarum libri duo', chapter 55, where he agrees in the order and method of laws [pandectes], refuting the innovators, who busy themselves with amending this method.
